t5M35xPzL2l1QOeaLlWi0A.text: The Goa green curry (added a side of rice) was fantastic. Incredibly flavorful with just the right amount of spice. My husband really liked his tandoori quail appetizer as well.

EQzCoqhNsHiWGwMQgIB8qA.text: I am not a big fan of Indian food. After eating at Chutney Mary I will say that I am. Upscale and beautifully decorated.The food was prepared as to my liking. I am not into spicy food so the kitchen made my food less spicy. I enjoyed my dinner as did all of the guests at my table. While I was eating dinner, the royal family from Dubai was eating next to me. Clearly this is a place well liked.

bE2g68tci_Cf2NbJlo0lWQ.text: I'm a huge fan of Indian cuisine and more adventurous and fusion type Indian and was hopeful when I discovered this place. We started with their signature cocktails and we were excited for the food since the cocktails were good. We ordered their tasting menu along with the wine pairing. What a huge mistake!Not only is it not worth the money but the wine pairing was absolutely embarrassing. There was no sommelier to explain anything about the wine, the wines were simply placed hoping we would figure out what they were by sipping on them. The food was just ok and some dishes were even mediocre at best. The service... I would say it was perhaps the worst of the entire experience. Since the food and the wines were mediocre you can guess what the service was like. Just because they wear a fancy outfit doesn't translate to an impressive service. I highly doubt I'd be going back... Terribly disappointed since I wanted to visit their other restaurants since I'm a huge foodie and in London quite often.

deGlgrTAa75FsktVUsZuMQ.text: All I can say is - wow!  Every year I try to take my daughter someplace interesting for her birthday.  This year was London.  And we wanted to have a nice dinner one evening.  A good friend recommended this spot, and it didn't disappoint.  The food was great, the ambience very cool, and the staff incredibly friendly.  The topper though was that I'd informed them it was my daughter's birthday, and at the conclusion of dinner they brought out an amazing cupcake for her.  Definitely a great place.

oKl-WzGNlMoTSqijOF1DRA.text: Great Indian food!  This was recommended by our hotel concierge and it was excellent, even if a bit pricey.  The dinning rooms were gorgeous and the service spot on.

zx0KF2S5xBGIn0njt264mA.text: The most amazing Indian food I've had in my life. The service staff were great. A must visit place for foodies

djcm06hlbTS2wM0z-oDV-Q.text: Really a great experience overall. The interior decor is mesmerizing - rich and beautifully decorated with perfect lighting.  We were a party of 7 and ordered a host of small plates and mains. The chicken tikka masala stood out in particular. Service was fantastic. Highly recommend.

qlouOnKIiFWf-DtNcaQwlA.text: This is a great, great Indian restaurant.   It's pricey, but well worth it.   We had some curries for entrees and a number of appetizers, everything was great.  The cocktails are well made.   The decor is hip and very nice.   The service is efficient but could be a little more personable, thus the 4 star rating.   It felt like our waiter was trying to take our order as fast as humanly possible ... and he seemed annoyed that I was asking a lot of questions.   If you want to have a five star restaurant, in my book, you need five star service.

I-gTG1mH16H9I4COwJsdAw.text: Had a fabulous meal here.  Took my Indian BF who also approved!   The venison appetizer is a must.  Butter chicken yes!  Lamb biryani!!!!

9mob_sleAFEjoUjSknrkrA.text: Stellar experience. Went for dinner while visiting London for the summer. Food was good quality as was service. It was not very crowded which was nice for having a pleasant pace.

UnA8z4WGrtqRNsjerER5mA.text: We stumbled upon Chutney Mary's having left Prince Charles at Lancaster House after fundraiser for Asian Elephants, you may see the designer Tuk Tuk  scooting around London, where almost 750,000 pounds sterling was raised. Chutney Mary's was right there so why not pop in for after garden party nibbles what. There was a wait for a table with a party of six at 22:00 on a Tuesday so keep that in mind. Bar area absolutely just so with exotic drinks and a bit of spicy something or other whilst waiting.  We moved to our table and enjoyed mutton, chicken, and veggie and vegan dishes which were tasty but not sure better than Zain.

4KlGjZPXBi1XpGqZTCxNcA.text: We had a pre-fix menu so I could not tell really how great the food could have been.  It was ok - I have had much better Indian food in the US but the presentation, staff, service, etc were are top notch.  5-star for the service, 3-stars for the food - hence my average of 4!

bpHaxT5gPtmgTJ0K8A867w.text: We did not have a reservation but the hostess sat 7 of us at lovely table in the bar. The service was great. Helpful and pleasant. We ordered small plates off the bar menu and we all found the quality of the food delicious and plentiful. Our waiter recommended we try the Afghani Chicken and it was absolutely delicious. Nice spiced, very tender and great with some Naan. We also ordered Butter Chicken, small samosas and lamb sliders. All delicious. Will definitely return on my next trip. The bar was so good I may not reserve In the restaurant.

45WQdFLlydOWrauUHUAe9w.text: For my first venture into Indian cuisine, I think this experience will be pretty hard to top.First off, the service and interior of the restaurant were both sublime. My family was in awe of how beautiful the space is, and the waiter was incredibly helpful when we went to order--he put in a few orders of sides to go with what we had already ordered for us. Additionally, the waitstaff so attentive, always there to help me as I tried pouring more cocktail (Pimms, mint, fruit, lemonade--it was awesome!!) into my glass.Now, the food. I had the butter chicken, and it came out in a small dish that was heating it. I poured the chicken and sauce over my rice, and oh my was the flavor incredible! My brother's lamb was also so tender it fell apart--it was a table favorite. I loved my first experience with Indian food, and thanks to Chutney Mary, I will definitely be eating more of it.

NkdhnZ68sn-WBkG_jC6Isw.text: A wonderful, beautifully decorated, inviting, friendly, yet upscale Indian restaurant.  Reservations are necessary, even in the tables in the main entrance room with the bar.  I had a vegetarian thali that was just so well-balanced and spiced, though it used more Western ingredients:  couscous, broccoli, stuffed peppers, yet carefully marinated in Indian spices, carefully displayed. I'd love to come back for some of the meat dishes which looked incredible.  I do think the spice level's been scaled back a bit.The cocktails here were also nicely crafted.  I quite enjoyed my Rangpur Gimlet with Tanqueray Rangpor, kafir lime, and dill leaves.  I'd definitely return.  It seems great for a date or work dinner or dinner with friends.  It's got a pleasant buzz -- not too loud, but warm and inviting.  The service was attentive but by no means overbearing.  A lovely spot!

jT1S24anSO-g3jYP1ViVwQ.text: I was looking for great Indian food in London.  Was recommended this spot from a local.  It is the best!  I have heard there is a Michelin star Indian restaurant in Mayfair, but not exactly what I was looking for.  Maybe next time.  This place was perfect.Great starters and main courses.  I did fois gras and a plate with several types of chicken.  My friend did all vegetarian and was very happy.Great drink menu too! I will be back for sure!  It's a must try in London, yes London is also known for its Indian food.  Yummmmmm

fNwoZHycHJRfVoQnAJD73A.text: We were visiting London and fancied some Indian food.  This spot came highly recommended from our mates in America.   The restaurant was beautifully appointed with a stylish bar and classy dining room.   We had a party of 5 so basically ordered a bit of everything.   All the food was very tasty with nice mix of flavors.  Our favorites were the venison samosa, butter chicken, calamari, Afghan chicken tikka, garlic naan and soufflé.   The only negative was the service.  Might of just been our waiter but he seemed very distracted and did not listen to my requests.  For such a nice restaurant, the service should match the decor and food.

PoOQkWlk_mzN93M9AGF01g.text: The atmosphere was great. The staff was great. And most importantly, the food was great. If I'm ever back in London. I'll definitely visit this place.

Yoxr-TczFYX5jFh_Dd00rA.text: One of our favorite restaurants in London. If you like Indian food you should definitely try this place out. Samosa starters and Chicken Tikka are worth including in your orders. Mulled wine during the Holiday season was an added bonus this trip

xTxrjKWAgEcBl3DmAV6gxA.text: Really great service and food! The Tandoori chicken was the juiciest moistious chicken I have ever had! Beautiful ambiance too!

l4BrZ8t1EhBA4KbdM6qp3A.text: To be honest I was a little disappointed by this place. I'd been looking forward to coming here for a while since they moved from their original location in Chelsea (which was great). First impressions were good. A doorman opened the door and we were showed to reception to check our coats. The dining room is pretty cool with good ambiance but not as spectacular as I was expecting based on other reviews.Anyway so the meal:I had the rose and lychee martini which was a very nice cocktail. Not too sweet. £13 though.My starter was the lobster chilli fry which was awesome. Really tender lobster pieces with just the right level of spice. Pricey at £19 but it was a decent portion of lobster and like I said, tasted fantastic.For the main I had the vegetarian silver crescent which is a selection of veggie stuff (creamed spinach, lentil curry, okra and paneer kofta). If I'm honest the main left me a little disappointed. It was all good enough (the kofta was actually very good) but didn't strike me as amazing. I found the naan bread a little dry and tasteless too which is shame.So I was generally disappointed because while everything was good, it didn't seem to justify the very high prices (lobster excluded).Service was again ok but not amazing. I think I'm comparing in my head to Veeraswamy which is a slightly higher level.My dining companions were pretty happy with their meals and they looked pretty good so maybe I just went wrong with my main. I would still go back to try their prawn curry.

q8KzEqxNEkdfPMH_zPaqkw.text: The St James restaurant is a reinvented version of he erstwhile Fulham shop. And how! Chutney Mary comes pretty damn close to what I would call the perfect cooking without stylising. I suppose you will say that that is somewhat debatable, after you've tried the boneless chicken wings starter.Starters: duck salad, boneless chicken wings, and crab cakes. All excellent.The biryani at Chutney Mary gets the gold. The portions are sumptuously adequate. The presentation is elegant. The spicing and tempering is just right. The kosha mangsho is almost perfect with the exception of the absence of potatoes. No Bengali cooking of meat goes without potatoes, however sophisticated the cooking style.The prawn curry is divine. The chef uses an orgasmically adequate amount of mustard paste in the cooking to stir the taste of the audience, and the result is a revelation of sorts. The date kulfi is worth trying, and uses the Bengali date molasses in the ice cream.Come prepared to eat a hearty meal, and you will have a close to emotional experience at this reinvented restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. The food
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. All of us, Saturday lunch
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom

hJv0THjHT95WhTF0t8jEIQ.text: Great place if you work near by or want to take a break while touring St. James Park, and/or the palace.Great service, with friendly staffs. Food was awesome. Had very tender and juicy chicken and lamb. The environment was a bit formal but also kids friendly ( I brought my two kids). The price is on the high side.

MHbp-DLAmdi7gQgA59D5rw.text: I was in the area and decided to stop in for a quick dinner. I'm incredibly picky about Indian food and so I send my compliments to the chefs for the fabulous food last week. Decor is lovely! I definitely think the menu is incredibly well designed and balanced. Service needs to be slightly more sophisticated.

bwpknY25XKsofWwfjFHkJQ.text: One of the best Indian meals of my life!  I highly recommend the tasting menu. You will not regret it.  It is pricier than the traditional Indian menu but it is well worth it.

6JTDDf1VYMm3Nr2Dx3NMmQ.text: Had dinner at Chutney Mary last night and my husband and I were suitably impressed!Ambiance: This restaurant is beautiful and more importantly very clean. I thought it was interesting that children aren't allowed after a certain time, but we were able to fob off the mini-me so it didn't end up being a problem. Also interesting that we had trouble getting a 7:30 reservation, because there were several empty tables throughout the 1.5 hours we enjoyed dinner. Service: Pretty good overall...definitely took a while for someone to take our order but aside from that no complaints.Food: Excellent!-- Crab cakes are fantastic. Definitely order these.-- Trio of Tikkas are a bit spicy but the beetroot tikka was phenomenal. I highly recommend this dish.-- Husband enjoyed the Chicken Tikka but commented on the spice level being a bit high.-- Saag was kind of a miss. It was too spicy and the consistency was a bit off-putting.-- Basmati rice as just okay. Nothing special.-- Spelt naan (plain and garlic) were delicious. A must order.Overall we left Chutney Mary rather contented. Prices were reasonable, service was good, and nothing was too greasy. My only complaint is the spice level is a bit high but aside from that we'll definitely return!

uM3JxwP891OzZhBl_19YFA.text: Having gotten a personal recommendation and read the overwhelmingly positive yelp reviews, we were looking forward to our lunch at Chutney Mary.  We were the second table to arrive and only a few came in after us and it still took a full 35 minutes to get our food (just two entrees and a side of dal and rice - no appetizers or other drinks).  The wait certainly colored the experience as we found the food to be good but not amazing.  And certainly not worth waiting that long for lunch service with so few people in the restaurant.  Especially given that there are many excellent Indian restaurants in London that would have been a fraction of the price we paid.  Also made a "tourist" mistake - when they asked if we wanted still or sparkling water, we said still water, not realizing that still water is bottled water (not tap water), which costs $5 pounds per bottle.  Since the dal was spicier than expected, we went through two bottles.  Don't make our mistake and spend almost $15US on water!

tWVEZVyQmMeSR45p-ATihg.text: Absolutely outstanding. So glad we stumbled upon this place. Lunch for four. We had a variety of dishes and everything was a flavor explosion. Crabcakes, vegetable platter, palak paneer, prawns, Lamb curry.... nothing disappointed. Put this place on your agenda! (would be a beautiful spot for a business lunch or dinner, by the way)

5QDFrfJh8qHoNvPc0ABQig.text: Good food, very spicy, high prices tho.  We started with the scallops appetizer (3 tiny scallops but very tasty).  The venison samosas were full of gamey venison.  Tasty and the sauces were good.  The spice definitely left its mark with lots of water.  For our main course, we had the prawns with the tomato based sauce.  Very spicy as well.  The naan was so soft and pillowy but we also felt that given how cheap rice is, they did not give you enough.  I was not that enamored with the dessert which was a creme brûlée with cardamom ice cream.  The custard was a little too thick for my taste but it was okay.  I think next time I will plan to order the soufflé ahead of time.This is definitely a "hip Indian place" with a very active bar and the restaurant has a very nice date-like feel.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Venison Samosa
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Scallops appetizer

tWB_iSmRVhtCJebrRe6L0A.text: Beautiful interiors, easily got a table at the last minute, and flavors were good. Service was top notch. Drinks are delicious and plating is beautiful. Deducting one star as I felt a lot of the curries and the chaat had overwhelming sweet taste. I had the veg tasting menu and it was plentiful and delicious. The madras coffee kulfi is out of the world.

1E89YXzScQWNIg9_1bHfxQ.text: Sadly, Chutney Mary has changed. This used to be my favorite restaurant in London when I lived there, so I brought my whole family while visiting from the US. I booked online, and my reservation confirmation stated that children only above the age of 8 are permitted in the dining room and only from 6 to 8 PM.  I was relieved, because my kids were both over the age of 12. Unfortunately, this policy is lip service only. We were seated right next to two children under the age of two, who screamed the whole time, ruining our experience. When I complain to our server and asked to be seated elsewhere, he refused. Only when we got up to leave did the manager come over and seat us in the actual dining room.(Before, we were seated in the front lounge.) The manager told us no children are permitted in the actual dining room, and we could only be seated in the front lounge because of our kids but he would make an exception this time. However, we were told we only had 45 minutes to eat because another party was booked after us. Because of this compressed timeframe, I think they skimped on the quality of the food, because there was nothing special about our meal. Also, we noticed plenty of children in the dining room, so again, I felt like the children policy in the restaurant was inconsistent. We paid over £300 for a very lackluster meal. There are plenty of better upscale Indian restaurants in London. I will not be bringing my family (or my clients for the matter) back here again ever.

D5kDSJcU2W7yhUh1lHnJbA.text: A friend of mine went here and absolutely loved it. She was raving about how great the service was, tasty the food, fabulous the drinks, yada yada yada. I can only think I went on an off day. Walking in, I thought it was gorgeous. However, it was a bit strange - being there had been a door guy and everything - that there wasn't anyone to greet us inside. I stood looking around at the bar in confusion for a while before spying the host stand at the other end of the room. Quickly we were checked in and brought to our table and that's when things took a turn. We order a couple drinks. Or rather we tried too. The first one they didn't have and the second one - a peach infused bourbon Old Fashioned- we were told they were out of peach liqueur..... Which was not listed in the ingredients. When we asked, the server looked confused and told us it was actually a liqueur. Oooookkkkk.....We grabbed a basic Bloody Mary and the Kafir Lime Gimlet with the ingredients listed as Gin, Kafir Lime and Dill. Dry, tart and boozy was what I was expecting, yet alas, sweet, syrupy and not at all what I wanted was what i experienced. Que my sad face. When we went for a second round, we asked the waiter about it and he said that they didnt actually list all the ingredients for the cocktails. But what about allergies? Oh surely people will tell them, right? Um.... And then the food. It wasn't bad. In fact, it was probably alright even bordering on good, but nothing really stood out. Plus our waiter messed up our order repeatedly. Like bringing dishes we hadn't ordered and having the curry come with rice when we had asked for the other option (lemon quinoa), which we then waited 15 min to arrive (meaning the curry had grown cold) only to be told that the quinoa doesn't go with the curry. Thanks pal. So glad you told us that to start with.Moral of this story? If you want Indian, there are so many other others. Do yourself a favour.

Gskjtk5H2AfzW4KoJDErlg.text: Very rich, vibrant, lovely atmosphere!  Honestly love the decoration for an Indian restaurant. Not sure what it was called but it was new on the menu...The green lamb curry was cooked perfectly! Slid off the bone easily cut with a spoon and the spice and little hint of coconut went perfectly with the dish.  If your looking for somewhere to find good curry/Indian  cuisine I highly recommend.

RgW_fRyW_IDOPSlhfr8s-w.text: Loved it! High end Indian food in a posh setting. Had the tasting menu which I would highly recommend. The chicken curry was fantastic!

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom

oGjJFh856UOeLR5lKNPIlw.text: Although it may sound like a type of Indian pickle, Chutney Mary is one of London's favorite upscale settings for South Asian food. It's known for being contemporary and cutting edge, all this panache congruous to glossy St James address.I came here with a group of 20 for a set menu dinner. As far as the food went, it was not fiercely spiced and had good flavoring. The 4 pot serving dish consisted of: Mangalore Prawn, Butter Chicken, Lamb, and Spinach Lasooni Palak, giving you a teaser of everything. The starter was a prawn meets chicken dish. The dessert was...not memorable.I didn't see anything particularly unusual or innovative in the food itself. Perhaps this is the downfall of the set menu. The service was fine, if not a touch slow. As glamorous as the boundless upstairs space is, with  turquoise and mahogany color palette and sparkling glass, the private dining room downstairs left me feeling slightly scrunched.

r_DIGUc8x3gIp8ntuEXyZQ.text: We had an awesome dinner experience the food; ambiance; service all were stellar. Until the assistant manager came over to tell us that he needed our table for other guest. Who had been waiting for our table. This ruined what otherwise would have been a fabulous evening. After several back and forth with the assistant manager. We were able to meet with Mr. Singh. Who agreed that we were treated poorly and was very apologetic said that he would comp our meals. We left the resturant feeling vindicated and appreciated; however after looking at our receipt for the refund the assistant manager (jerk) only took off €20. Needless to say we were very disappointed and will never, ever return again to Chutney Mary's. These folks are not honorable and are sexist and discriminatory. We were a table of highly educated professional woman - this was totally unsatisfactory treatment.

3LcmWGCXGnZXXGe3njGxpQ.text: Extremely poor service. Food was terribly cooked - cold, processed. We happen to sit next to a food critic who got all the attention that night while the rest of us were ignored. Do not recommend this restaurant.

Y1SUfNbzbiW00TpYQhhE6Q.text: Chutney Mary's is an old favourite of all Indian food loving Londoners (& visitors), despite its old Chelsea Address (& basement layout). The new CM in St. James is a great location, very swank, & a terrifically designed restaurant. The decor is beautiful, & they have amazing floral arrangements.But we're here for the food... which is as good as ever!Venison samosas: amazing (nice & spicy!); Quail: delicious; Kashmiri chicken:GTFO; Butter Chicken: OTC; Kadai creme brulee: GET OUUUUUUTT!!Service was stellar, & I only wish they had more choices in the sub-£75 wines, otherwuse it would get 5-stars.Go. Often.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee (with gold leaf, lol)
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Quail & blueberry chutney

LFeqUG6YSVYw7E7V3TECQQ.text: Not good for a lone female diner.  I came in after passing it a few times on the way to my hotel and wanting to try it. I asked to sit at the bar, but they said a table would be more comfortable. OK. I ordered an appetizer a Cocktail.  The first was okay  the cocktail was good. If a waiter had asked me if I wanted to try something else, I would have.  But, it was like I wasn't there.  This is why I like to eat at the bar when I am by myself.  Eventually, they noticed me again and I paid my bill and left.

AjZ8fqZ-NOcYbriPVoQtXA.text: One of the place we'll return to when visiting London again. Partner had the lamb shank - nalli  gosht - and stated it was the best he's ever had and he loves ordering lamb shank everywhere he sees it on a menu. Prawn curry was delish as well as the apps. As far as high end Indian food goes, this is a winner. We liked it more than Rasika in DC.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Menu Dec 2017
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Prawn curry

nszWSti1-FwPhqubcDcXxQ.text: I am so out of my element to write this review. After the theater let out we ran as fast as we could to get here in time to eat. Afzal was our server. He put us right at ease and let us relax into our dinning experience. Not sure even what to order we let our server be our guide. We started with the fried squid and shrimp. Both amazing. We did the lamb chops, green curry chicken  and garlic naan for our entrees. Finished off our dinner with the lime tart. Our tastebuds have been on an amazing journey. This dinner gets an overall wow. I can't put in words what I'm feeling now. Beautiful food, amazing atmosphere and spot on service.  One can not ask for more.

l-_F7Uw4mfaBKkJf5Fj2uQ.text: We were originally planning to go to Dishoom; but, we were running a little late and didn't want to wait in the long line so we opted for Chutney Mary around the corner from our office. I was really glad that we did. I've had my share of good Indian food in London and Chutney Mary is at the top of the list. It is a sister restaurant of another favorite of mine, Veeraswamy. The Indian food in the U.K. is much more sophisticated than what we are used to in the States; not every Indian place has a buffet and is cheap. The cooking style at Chutney Mary is very sophisticated. The ambiance is clubby upscale and much of the weekday evening clientele consists of the investment bankers from the nearby offices. Everything we ordered was fantastic. The flaky Cornish crab garlic butter was a small dish of lumps of crab meat sautéed in ample butter and spices served with some naan. The calamari with lime and chili chutney was another delightful appetizer. The wild Madagascar prawns were large (the size of a small fist) with the perfect texture. The butter chicken is similar to chicken tikka masala and was delicious; we were using the garlic naan to wipe up the sauce.  The biryani (forgot the name but it's vegetarian) was exceptional and the server suggested adding yogurt (pomegranate infused), which gave it an extra layer of flavors. All the other dishes we had were all superbly prepared. I'd say this is my new favorite Indian restaurant in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Calamari with chili lime chutney- tender in the inside and crispy on the outside. The chutney was brilliant.
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Flaky Cornish crab in garlic butter. Incredible flavors.
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian biryani - one of my favorite dishes here

KFnIWpkzDkbqVTIxeap6uQ.text: Hi end Indian cuisine in a modern surrounding. A little overpriced and small portions but the food is excellent and full of flavour. Staff were a little snooty on the phone and in person. Had a reservation and showed up on time but needed to wait a bit for the table. We all enjoyed the food, but I must say that I prefer the more hole in the wall kind of Indian places. Samosas were scrumptious as was the calamari. Curried potato was fabulous and the chicken curry was full of amazing spices.The fish tandoori was delicious too.

T_gOsZ1Kp08w77-I1QBYwA.text: So amazing. So worth the price. The restaurant is gorgeous, the staff is knowledgeable, efficient and very helpful. The cocktails are unusual and very tasty. The food is the real star of the show. The food is remarkable, truly remarkable. The venison samosas were an explosion of flavor from the first bite. Spicy and flavorful and the sauces just added to the intensity. I had a lamb dish that was fall off the bone tender. The flavor was so incredible, we used our naan to clean the bowl. The butter chicken was every bit as good. We had easily the best Indian food of my life. I was left with the warm, spicy burn at the back of my throat. Not too much just enough to keep me thinking about the meal for the rest of the night (and dreaming about my next visit).

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom

W2V7H--WO-yxkNXnvqRUoQ.text: Holy moly was our experience here amazing. The hubby and I were in town on vacation and (stereotypically) needed to have Indian food while in London. On our last night in town, we found Chutney Mary via Yelp and walked in on a week night without reservation. The restaurant looks small from the outside, but seemed to continue forever inside. It was actually relatively packed, so we snagged a pair of seats at a large, beautiful wood communal table.We were very hungry and almost ordered everything on the menu, but decided to stick with the premium prix fixe menu. I wish I could remember everything that was served, but let's just say we ate every single drop of food on our plates and wished the night would never end. The staff were on point and very in tune to our needs. I will recommend this place to everyone!!

psJEgri45YmIQTdvXUwPcg.text: Chutney Mary was a recommendation we had gotten for our recent trip to London, and since we haven't eaten as much Indian as I would have liked in our past trips here, we decided to stop by for a Christmas Eve lunch. We were the first folks in when we came shortly after noon, and even by the time we had left 1.5 hours later, the main dining room had a handful of tables filled at most, with a few more parties out in the more casual setting out front. What I really liked is how the decor fused Indian sensibilities, particularly the bright colors, with a very modern, cosmopolitan sense of dining. It felt much more effortless than similar restaurants I have been to in NYC. The only drawback of the entire experience was the service...after we were seated, we had to flag down the waiter to put our order in, as well as request still water for the table. I write that off a little to us being the first people in the door, but it showed a lack of attention. The drink list is interesting, with standard cocktails coming with an Indian twist, as well as a selection of some English craft beers (there's a wine list as well, but I didn't really look at it).For lunch, there is a 2-course and 3-course prix fixe option (the 3-course version gives you dessert for an extra 5 pounds); we went with the 2-course option, which was by far enough food, and ordered a dal makhani on the side (in hindsight, probably too much). Everything here was excellent, as well as being a decent amount of food to boot. I started out with the lamb burger sliders, which I really enjoyed - very flavorful and succulent, with a Western-style presentation but very much infused with Indian spices and flavors. Our mains were similarly excellent, with my wife's lobster biryani really standing out. The rice was infused with the spiced aroma of seafood, and the lobster was quite delicious. I had never tasted a seafood-based biryani before, but this was excellent. I did something a little more along traditional lines (for me), sticking with the butter chicken curry. I enjoyed the balance of the sauce - lots of tomato, but with just the right amount of butter and cream to cut the curry. I would have liked the chicken cut into slightly smaller pieces, but that is a very minor nitpick on a curry dish that is better than pretty much any curry I have eaten in the past.While the cost for lunch felt high, it was a much better value than the previous day's meal, and for London, it seemed about the kind of price to expect. The location is great, the ambiance is fantastic, and the food is excellent. I'd definitely recommend a stop here for a meal - everything was top-notch, with only the service being something that could use a little work.

2j1JzIvDk2IW3NwdYfmB3Q.text: The atmosphere is very classy, and the prices match the fine dining experience. I had the Afghan chicken tikka, garlic naan, basmati rice, and garlic spinach. The clear winner for this meal was the spinach. All the others were also high quality, but the spinach had that Indian spice that made the rest delicious.The only reason I'm rating this as a 4 and not a 5 is the slower service. I was here on a Friday night in London, so perhaps my expectations for service are too American. But if you know that you have the time and money to enjoy the experience here, it's certainly worth the visit!

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Atmosphere inside the restaurant before it filled up with people.
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Afghan chicken tikka, rice, spinach, and garlic naan

Fxis-PKTsFWWYYcQdf9m6A.text: It was way over priced for the small portions and the taste of the food. The curry did not have the satisfying flavor or taste I was looking for. I spent £200 and left unhappy and still hungry.

upoQZKsxpioulozwzDpmVA.text: Dreamy, best Indian food I've ever eaten. I can't believe how good the vegetarian dishes were... it shocked us. The samosas are a MUST.

IcVLhFVgYY5vvD6bCv_M7g.text: Well, from my point of view here you can find one of the very best Indian restaurants in London. Well sorted and equipped bar, all Gins, good selection of wines. Only a proper champagne is far away. Anyhow, the meal is outstanding delicious. The service is very competent and friendly. The price is not for everybody, keeps the tourists out.

lo4LRVw7iLyO65icSVUv8A.text: The gourmet tasting menu, with wine. Don't miss. The selections for this change on a regular enough basis that it's a new revelation every time. If you come early for your reservation, you can be seated early. But if you come late, you might miss your meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom

PhEtE3EB9yohhub_2do0jg.text: I should start by saying that I don't usually choose to eat Indian food, maybe once a year.  However, This is my new favorite restaurant and a must for anyone going to London.  Enjoyed a nice chilled cocktail at the bar to relax after a long day of sightseeing, then headed into the restaurant which is beautiful.  Service was amazing from the moment we sat down.  Traditional menu with some unique and interesting options.  Well informed servers guided us through the menu and the food was amazing and beautifully presented.  The food was truly exceptional.  We shared a variety of dishes and everything was delicious.  Hands down one of the best restaurants I've been to.  Pictures are of the bar area - not the actual restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Pictures are of the bar - which was very nice
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom

83NlkAcXGSvD_Vldcxejkg.text: Hot and Cold.So, I missed the debate a few years back on whether meals at Indian restaurants should cost 70 quid per person. Like many people in the US who're stuck on seeing Indian restaurants as cheap lunch buffets, there's a large number of people in the U.K. that seem to equate cheap curries with good Indian food. It's an unfair generalization for I don't see cuisines like French, Italian, or Japanese put in that bucket. Personally, I don't have an issue in shelling out 70 pounds for a meal at an Indian restaurant, as long as the price point is warranted by the food quality, some innovation in technique or pairing of ingredients in a manner that leads to dishes that I've not seen elsewhere. But, I do have an issue when at the end of the meal I leave thinking that 2/3 of the bill was paying for swanky premises, upscale decor, art, mahogany, antiques, chandeliers, carpets etc. - as opposed to the craftsmanship of a chef (and his/her team) that truly wowed or surprised me.Sadly, for me Chutney Mary falls in that category of restaurants. The dining room is undeniably grand and stunning. But, as far as food goes, whenever I liked something in a dish, there would be a counterpoint that bothered. The Cornish crab itself may have excelled in taste and texture, but the pool of melted garlic butter left me with the same heavy feeling I get after eating greasy curries. Speaking of greasy, if I wanted a Paratha I would have ordered one. I'm not exactly sure why the garlic naan seemed dabbed in a wet rub of garlic instead of minced garlic cloves. Presenting Gajjar Halwa as a soufflé was interesting, but it didn't really pair well with the pistachio ice cream. I tried the elements separately and then together and ended up keeping the two different temperatures and textures apart from each other as I found that better. But, I did debate what a baked Alaska of the two combinations would taste like (food for thought for the management) :)My favorite item was the Tandoori Grouse served with Masala chips which showcased all the joys one associates with Indian cuisine: heat, aromatic spices, and dry (as opposed to an Olympic pool of) curry.The service was attentive and even the manager dropped in regularly to check in on me. That will keep them in good stead with the smartly dressed families that seemed regulars at the restaurant. I think the owners know their market to a T: well heeled folks who were dropped off by their chauffeur in a Bentley. But, pretension never works for me, and so I'll probably try the other restaurants in their empire (Amaya, Veeraswamy) on my next visit to London.

Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Tandoori Grouse
Photo of Chutney Mary - London, United Kingdom. Garlic Naan
